text:
<@UKQT95T1V> Good list.

– There may even be an arrow A → C, that isn't the composition of an arrow A → B with an arrow B → C.  These sorts of qualities are what give a category its categorical structure.  Given an arrow like with and an arrow like that, does there exist an arrow that relates to them in some special way?

– Yes, many arrows on a single object.  When monoids and groups are treated as categories, they have *one* categorical object with each element of the group being a morphism, the identity element as the identity morphism, and the binary operator as composition.  And yes, identities end up being unique.  <https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Identity_Morphism_is_Unique>  I misspoke earlier.

– id ∘ id = id.

text: By the way friends, I like to meet while outside because family is sleeping, Hong Kong apartments are tiny, and who would turn down a view like this?

elements.text: By the way friends, I like to meet while outside because family is sleeping, Hong Kong apartments are tiny, and who would turn down a view like this?

text: The intuition about sets is that elements are distinguishable, you can give them names, therefore you can interchange them. A function between sets is a special kind of relation. A relation is just a set of pairs. So if you have a set {a, b}, you can have a function (set of pairs) {(a, b), (b, a)}, which maps a to b and b to a. Another function is {(a, a), (b, a)} (constant function). On the other hand, {(a, a), (a, b)} is not a function (but it is a relation). Identity is {(a, a), (b, b)}. Hope this helps.

elements.text: The intuition about sets is that elements are distinguishable, you can give them names, therefore you can interchange them. A function between sets is a special kind of relation. A relation is just a set of pairs. So if you have a set {a, b}, you can have a function (set of pairs) {(a, b), (b, a)}, which maps a to b and b to a. Another function is {(a, a), (b, a)} (constant function). On the other hand, {(a, a), (a, b)} is not a function (but it is a relation). Identity is {(a, a), (b, b)}. Hope this helps.
